It does need to sit in the fridge overnight to achieve its creamy texture, so plan accordingly. Watch Priya Krishna make shahi toast here.Recipe adapted with permission from Indian-ish by Priya Krishna with Ritu Krishna (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt). Copyright © 2019. Ingredients4–6 servings2cups heavy cream6Tbsp. sugar1tsp. ground cardamom, preferably freshly ground2Tbsp. vegetable oil5slices white bread, crusts removed,  each slice cut into quarters2Tbsp. coarsely chopped pistachiosPreparationStep 1Coat bottom of a medium saucepan with 2 Tbsp. water (this will prevent the cream from sticking when you heat it). Add cream and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until warmed through, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat; add sugar and cardamom and stir until sugar is dissolved. Set aside.Step 2Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high until shimmering. Reduce heat to medium-low and, working in batches if needed, cook bread until golden brown and crisp, about 5 minutes per side.Step 3Arrange bread in a 9x9" baking dish in a single layer. Give reserved cardamom cream a stir to reincorporate, then pour over bread, making sure each piece is fully saturated. Cover with plastic wrap and chill at least 8 hours and up to 2 days.Step 4Top bread pudding with pistachios just before serving.How would you rate Cardamom Bread Pudding?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (4)Back to TopTriangleEnjoyed this simple dessert. Nice flavours, making it for the third time. AnonymousNew Brunswick Canada3/10/2021This was very good! I'm half Iranian so cardamom and pistachios are a flavor I grew up eating in desserts. I added a few threads of saffron for flavor/ color. Tastes like gulab jamun and kheer had a baby (or maybe just reminded me of ras malai?). 
 If you like kulfi or Persian ice cream/baklava this would be good with a TBL (or less) rosewater added to the milk mixture when you stir in the sugar/cardamom. If you're not used to rose try a teaspoon in the mixture and go from there.  All my roomies liked it, will be making again. AnonymousSan Diego, CA 5/8/2020This was terrible.  2 Libra family members and neither  liked it.Anonymous117545/2/2020I made this recipe recently for a virtual form of a cookbook club I'm in. I love Priya's book, but there aren't many sweets and I love sweets so this was my choice. I made the recipe exactly as written and even used the whole cardamom pods (wow, amazing scent) and this was absolutely delicious. I didn't plan ahead enough and had to eat some prior to the pudding soaking for a full 8 hours, but it was still SO good and my husband and kids love it too. Very unique flavor and a great way to end a meal. This book overall is a winner and I love Priya!
